document.docAuthor: Maqbool, Amir, Akbar, Shahid Ali & Wachkoo, Aijaz Ahmad
document.docTitle: Ficobracon kashmirensis Maqbool & Akbar & Wachkoo 2018, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: First record of the genus Ficobracon (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) from India, with description of new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First record of the genus Ficobracon (Hymenoptera: Braconidae) from India, with description of new species

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis: Antenna with 23–26 antennomeres; first tergite without medial groove, sublateral grooves distinct; second tergite longitudinally rugulose with smooth medio-basal area surrounded by a rugose pair of grooves, sublateral grooves absent; third tergite longitudinally rugose. This species resembles most to
F. codonatus ,
and the two taxa can be readily separated by the absence of the medial groove on the first tergite and densely rugulose second tergite in
F. kashmirensis .

Description. Female ( Figs 1–13 ): Body length 3.70 mm ( 3.31–4.12 mm in paratypes ), fore wing length 4.07 mm ( 3.69–4.47 mm in paratypes ).

sp. nov.

Habitus, lateral view (1); dorsal view (2); ventral view (3); antennae (4); head, frontal view (5); head lateral view (6); mesosoma, dorsal view (7); mesosoma, lateral view (8); 1 st and 2nd tergite, dorsal view (9); mid and hind legs (10); metasoma, dorsal view (11); metasoma, lateral view (12); ovipositor sheath (13).

subSubSection.paragraph: Colour ( Figs. 1–3 , 15–17 ). Body light to dark yellowish brown; antenna, ventral part of mesopleuron, scutellar sulcus, propodeum, hind tibia, tarsal claws, first tergite, most of third tergite, ovipositor sheath, and pterostigma black to dark brown; groove of pronotum, propleuron, side of scutellum, largely dark brown to yellowish; second tergite medially dark brown, sometimes largely yellow; wings subhyaline.
Distribution. Jammu and Kashmir , Srinagar, India .

Biology. Both the fig species (
Ficus carica
and
Ficus palmata
) in Jammu and Kashmir are frequently visited by
Ficobracon kashmirensis
( Figs 28–31 ). The female wasp bores through the fig wall with its ovipositor and lays a single egg inside the unripe fig which hatches in around 22 hrs. Larvae show phytophagous behavior feeding on immature ovaries and form a cocoon to pupate after 11–13 days ( Figs 32–33 ). Adults emerge from cocoons in about 5–6 days and chew out a tunnel through the fig wall ( Fig. 34 ). Emergence starts in the month of July and continues till November. Different females may oviposit on the same fig and multiple cocoons are formed inside a single fig. Others usually follow the same initial tunnel but occasionally other tunnels are also bored. Sexual dimorphism is obvious with females larger ( 3.31–4.12 mm ) than males (2.70–3.19).
Etymology. Species epithet is in reference to the type locality.
